column3: Isn't `!` expected functionality for bigint arithmetic? I'm aware that we're not using it at the moment, but I'd like to invoke the principle of least surprise here
Agree with @laanwj \n@Empact - is the only benefit here to reduce binary size? I don't know enough about the linker to determine whether it will include this code even if currently unused
It's a function in the include file, so I would even doubt this affect the binary size. Also ti's properly tested so that can't be an argument to remove it either. ~~I'd say NACK, sorry.~~

<!--e57a25ab6845829454e8d69fc972939a-->Note to reviewers: This pull request conflicts with the following ones:

* #13388 (util: Implement boolean conversion and !operator for uint* by qmma70)

If you consider this pull request important, please also help to review the conflicting pull requests. Ideally, start with the one that should be merged first.

My motivation is to reduce lines of code because I view unused functionality as a tax on readers of the code, even if those lines don't impact the binaries. I guess you could say this is partly an expression of the YAGNI principle.
I opened a related PR #13388, if anyone's interested.

Oke, forget my argument about API symmetry. There is no `operator bool()` on `arith_uint256`, so why would `bool operator!()` exist. This means you can do `if (!a)` but not `if(a)`. Hmm.\n\nutACK 2acd1d6716959b99e751cf85a7c47aaa383e937f
